October 31, 1982: Fiction
SPACE, by James A. Michener. (Random House, $17.95.) The story of the
American space program told through fiction.
MASTER OF THE GAME, by Sidney Sheldon. (Morrow, $15.95.) The hidden truth
behind a woman business tycoon's rise to power.
THE VALLEY OF HORSES, by Jean M. Auel. (Crown, $15.95.) Continuing the
saga of human survival at the dawn of civilization begun in ''The Clan of the Cave
Bear.''
E.T. THE EXTRA-TERRESTRIAL STORYBOOK, by William Kotzwinkle. (Putnam,
$6.95.) Abridged, profusely illustrated version of the novelization of the current
film.
DIFFERENT SEASONS, by Stephen King. (Viking, $16.95.) Four novellas with
mainly nonhorror themes by a modern master of horror.
CROSSINGS, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $15.95.) A clandestine trans-Atlantic
romance survives the stresses and strains of World War II.
FOUNDATION'S EDGE, by Isaac Asimov. (Doubleday, $14.95.) The struggle to
keep civilization alive in a crumbling empire: fourth volume of s.f. stories in ''The
Foundation Trilogy.''
LACE, by Shirley Conran. (Simon & Schuster, $16.95.) Three decades in the lives
of a coterie of members of the international glitter set.
SPELLBINDER, by Harold Robbins. (Simon & Schuster, $14.95.) From soldier in
Vietnam to right-wing television superstar: the career of an evangelist.
CLOAK OF DARKNESS, by Helen MacInnes. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich,
$13.95.) The operator of a counterterrorist agency finds himself high on an
assassination list.
MAX, by Howard Fast. (Houghton Mifflin, $15.95.) The birth of the American film
industry in New York at the turn of the century.
THE PRODIGAL DAUGHTER, by Jeffrey Archer. (Linden Press, $15.95.) A
sequel to the author's ''Kane & Abel,'' in which two children of those antagonists
marry one another.
SECOND HEAVEN, by Judith Guest. (Viking, $14.95.) Two emotionally battered
souls, a man and a woman, are healed through the act of healing an emotionally
battered runaway boy.
LIFE, THE UNIVERSE AND EVERYTHING, by Douglas Adams. (Harmony,
$9.95.) On a journey through space, two Englishmen find answers to all their
October 31, 1982
Non-Fiction
JANE FONDA'S WORKOUT BOOK, by Jane Fonda. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.)
An exercise book for women, seasoned with the film star's philosophy of physical
well-being.
LIVING, LOVING & LEARNING, by Leo Buscaglia. (Holt/Slack, $13.50.)
Inspirational talks by a University of Southern California professor.
LIFE EXTENSION, by Durk Pearson and Sandy Shaw. (Warner, $22.50.) Ways to
add years to your life and life to your years: a popularly written medical-science
book.
WHEN BAD THINGS HAPPEN TO GOOD PEOPLE, by Harold S. Kushner.
(Schocken, $10.95.) Comforting thoughts from a rabbi.
THE ONE MINUTE MANAGER, by Kenneth Blanchard and Spencer Johnson.
(Morrow, $15.) How to increase the productivity of those with whom you work as
well as your own.
JANE FONDA'S WORKOUT BOOK FOR PREGNANCY, BIRTH AND
RECOVERY, by Femmy DeLyser. (Simon & Schuster, $16.95.) Advice from a
colleague of the film star.
THE G SPOT, by Alice Kahn Ladas, Beverly Whipple and John D. Perry. (Holt,
Rinehart & Winston, $11.95.) Recent discoveries about human sexuality.
AND MORE BY ANDY ROONEY, by Andrew A. Rooney. (Atheneum, $12.95.) A
new collection of essays by the journalist and television commentator.
INDECENT EXPOSURE, by David McClintick. (Morrow, $17.50.) The scandal at
Columbia Pictures and Wall Street's part in it.
ATLANTIC HIGH, by William F. Buckley Jr. (Doubleday, $22.50.) Log of a trans-
Atlantic crossing aboard a luxurious ketch.
NO BAD DOGS: The Woodhouse Way, by Barbara Woodhouse. (Summit,
$12.50.) Advice on training dogs by a British expert: tie-in to a television series.
WEIGHT WATCHERS FOOD PLAN DIET COOKBOOK, by Jean Nidetch. (NAL
Books, $13.95.) A new collection of nearly 600 recipes.
LANA: The Lady, the Legend, the Truth, by Lana Turner. (Dutton, $14.95.) The
film actress's autobiography.
A LIGHT IN THE ATTIC, by Shel Silverstein. (Harper & Row, $12.45.) Humor in
cartoons and verse.
A FEW MINUTES WITH ANDY ROONEY, by Andrew A. Rooney. (Atheneum,
